page.lettertext:
fol.218r
1594 21 July To
e L. T
re
r
Maye it please your good L. by your l
re
of
e 7 which I receaved the 19
having had full Intelligence
t
her
Ma
tie
is determined to goe forward w
th
her purpose for
e rescue of
Brest,
and to have
e assistance of
e
states
requyred thereunto, I mooved them in yt yesterday and had theyr aunswer
p
nt
ly; whiche was to this effect,
That
they have signified already by theyr l
re
s
to her Ma
tie
,
at they will strayne theyr abilitie to
e uttermost degree
to second her designe, and whenseover they may knowe her fynall resolution
they will p
nt
ly arme their Navie. For they thincke it very necessarie
at
they should firste be made acquaynted w
th
the tyme to sette forth, the
place of
e Rendez vous. the numbers of her shippes, soldiers, munition
powder and other provisions, w
th
all
e project of
e service, to
e ende they
maye proceede wth a sownde deliberation, and provyde them selves thereafter
of every thinge requisite. That otherwyse yf they should p
nt
ly sette
forward, it might befalle them at this tyme; as it would have done
before, upon my first proposition,
at in making speedely towardes
Portesmouth
and
Plimouth,
as was requyred ther of them, they should
have made a frutelesse
vyo
voyage, and burdened
e Contry wth a
ne
needlesse charge, for two or three monnethes, soe as nowe at this p
nt
,
they should have wanted
e meanes to yeald any succo
r
. In whiche
respecte they are desyrous to knowe of her Ma
tie
, her laste determi-
nation, w
th
every particular and necessarie circumstance, and
t
then for their portion, they will alwayes be as forward, as can in reason
be requyred. If I had knowne those
ticular demaundes
which it seemed by your l
re
s, her Ma
tie
proposed to theyr Agent
M
r
Caron
, I might better have bin able to negotiate w
th
them. For nowe
I could but deale in certaine generall termes, not knowing what
matter those demaundes might imparte. Heere is noe resolution
taken, for any further Imployment of theyr forces at home, the state
seeming bente to refreshe theyr Soldiers, for a whyle in their garrison
townes, for whiche I will be earnest, to gette those of her Ma
tie
to
be somewhat better furnished. They passed a promesse a greate whyle
since to
e Frenche
Kinge,
t
after
Groeninghen
was reduced, they would
spare hym 3000 footemen and 500 horse for
e space of three months
to be co
m
aunded by
e
Duke of Bouillon
, and employed as he thought good,
againste
e Contreys of
Artois,
and
Hennault
or any other place, to
e
annoyance of the Enemie. This promesse beyng made I suppose they
will perfourme, if
e Duke be ready for yt, and hath caste his plotte
to good effect, whereunto as it seeemeth they attend to knowe his aunsweare.
Theyr deputies for
Scotland
are upon theyr departure, whose p
nt
fol.218v
at
e Christening is twoe standing Cuppes of pure gold amounting
to
e value of 1200
li
ster
l
, and a certaine patent from
e
Provinces
inclosed also in a box of gold, conteyning the graunte of an annual
pension of 500
li
during the lyfe of
e young
Prince,
to be enjoyed by
hymself, or bestowed on any other. But this they are unwilling to be
publickly knowen.
Having noe other matter I take my humble
leave.
H
From
e Hage July 21
1594
.
To my L. T
re
r 21 July 1594
for the States provissyone to assyste hir Ma
tie
in the Jurney to Breste, their Aydinge of
Fraunce,
and a presente geven at the Christeninge of the Prince of Scotland.
36 Eli
z
.
